review.title: Naturalizing a Programming Language via Interactive Learning
review.abstract: Our goal is to create a convenient natural language interface for performing well-specified but complex actions such as analyzing data, manipulating text, and querying databases. However, existing natural language interfaces for such tasks are quite primitive compared to the power one wields with a programming language. To bridge this gap, we start with a core programming language and allow users to "naturalize" the core language incrementally by defining alternative, more natural syntax and increasingly complex concepts in terms of compositions of simpler ones. In a voxel world, we show that a community of users can simultaneously teach a common system a diverse language and use it to build hundreds of complex voxel structures. Over the course of three days, these users went from using only the core language to using the naturalized language in 85.9\% of the last 10K utterances.

sections.heading: 2 Voxelurn
sections.text: There are two domain-specific actions, "add" and "move," a domain-specific relationship "direction." In addition, the state contains a selection that includes a number of positions. While our focus is on Voxelurn, we can think more generally about the world as a set of objects that are endowed with relationships - events in a calendar, cells in a spreadsheet, or lines of text. The system is shaped by the understanding of a core language called "Action Language" (DAL), which we have created for an overview.

sections.heading: 3 Learning interactively from definitions
sections.text: The goal of the user is to build a structure in Voxelurn. In Wang et al. (2016), the user provided the system with interactive monitoring by selecting from a list of candidates. This is handy when there are fewer than ten candidates, but is completely unfeasible for a complex action space such as Voxelurn. Roughly speaking, 10 possible colors across the field 3 x 3 x 4 that contains the palm tree in Figure 2 result in 1036 unique denotations and many other programs. Obtaining the structures in Figure 1 by selecting candidates alone would be impracticable. This work uses definitions in addition to selecting candidates as a supervision signal. Each definition consists of a head utterance and a body that is a sequence of expressions that the system understands. One use of definitions is the paraphrase and definition of alternative syntax that helps to naturalize the core language (e.g. the definition of brown surfaces).

sections.heading: 4 Model and learning
sections.text: This section contains prerequisites before describing definitions and grammar rules in Section 5.Semantic Parsing. Our system is based on a semantic parser that can execute the meaningfulness of statements x to programs z (2016) for a gentle exposure. A derivative d represents the process by which an utterance x is turned into a program (d). Specifically, d is a tree in which each node contains the corresponding utterance (d), the grammar rule (d), the grammar category cat (d), and a list of child derivations (d).

sections.heading: 5 Grammar induction
sections.text: In this section, we will show you how to convert these definitions into new grammar rules that can be used by the system to analyze new expressions. Previous systems of grammar induction for semantic analysis were provided with expression program points (x, z). Although some rules are pronounced immediately, many wrong rules are still followed. In the interactive setting, we must keep the number of candidates small to avoid a bad user experience, which means that parts of x are associated with parts of z.

sections.heading: 5.2 Extending the chart via alignment
sections.text: Suppose that "upward combinations" are defined as "upward combinations," where "upward combinations" do not analyze and do not coincide with anything. We would like to conclude that "upward combinations" are synonymous with "up." To handle this, we can use a property of definitions that we have not used before: the utterances themselves. If we align the head and the body, then we would intuitively expect aligned phrases to correspond to the same derivatives. Under this assumption, we can then transfer these derivatives from dX to diagrams (x) to generate new matching (x). This is more limited than the usual alignment problem (e.g. in machine translation), since we only have to look at spans of X that correspond to derivatives in desc (dX).

sections.heading: 7 Related work and discussion
sections.text: This work is an evolution of Wang et al. (2016), but differs significantly in several aspects: While Wang et al. (2016) starts from zero and is based on the selection of candidates, this work starts with a programming language (PL) and additionally relies on definitions that allow us to scale. Instead of having a private language for each user, the user community shares a language in this work. Azaria et al. (2016) presents Learning by Instruction Agent (LIA), which also advocates user learning, arguing that developers cannot foresee all the actions that users want, and that the system cannot understand the corresponding natural language even when the desired action is built in. Like Jia et al. (2017), Azaria et al. (2016) begins with a series of initial slot-filling commands in natural language as the basis for further instructions - our approach starts with an expressive core PL language designed to interpolate with the language.
